Look on the bright side, Sarah, Judith and Al. The city may be crumbling, but it sure knows how to pick up the crumbs in a hurry.

On Thursday, when a water main burst under 42d Street, Armageddon seemed briefly at hand. Tunnels flooded, subways stopped, traffic froze. And because commuters from all five boroughs converge on Grand Central Terminal, the pain radiated outward, clogging an entire city.

But yesterday the sun shone, the trains ran (mostly), and things didn't look quite so bad. In fact, some things looked better than ever. The Grand Central subway platforms were flushed as close to squeaky clean as they'll ever be. And the subway tracks, usually a fetid heap of cigarette butts and soda cans, were magically rubbish-free. It was as if someone had dumped a vat of detergent down there and turned on the spigot.

True, 42d Street is a mess and some nearby shops were badly damaged. Ceiling panels collapsed in the subway station. And the fact that a six-foot-high wall of water actually surged from Manhattan to Queens through the Steinway Tube (a lovely name for a lowly tunnel) will doubtless linger in the minds of those who make the daily journey on the No. 7 train under the East River.

But the subway station is not ruined; a chastened city survives. Cheers, then, to the city workers who battled the rats, pumped out the water, shoveled the mud and turned Armageddon into just another routinely stressful New York day.
